Calculus and chromatic theory

Jul 2, 2019

I’m currently at UChicago, working with Mark Behrens and Peter May. It’s incredibly fun. I talked with Mark today for almost three and a half(!) hours about some really interesting stuff, and I’d like to better understand some of the story he told me about. That’s what I’ll try to do in this post. I don’t want to get bogged down in details for now, since I’m still trying to understand this stuff, so I’ll try to explain the big picture.

Let’s begin with the EHP spectral sequence. This uses the fiber sequence to obtain a filtration of , and hence define a spectral sequence with converging to , where the -differentials go . Since Serre tells us that is rationally just , this spectral sequence collapses at the -page.

Serre’s result suggests that we can maybe instead try to use the double suspension; this gets us a fiber sequence , where is the fiber of the double suspension. According to Serre, is a rational homotopy equivalence, so . Consequently, we get a filtration , and hence a spectral sequence with converging to (if I’ve got the indexing right). Since the -page vanishes rationally, we should try to invert .

One can define the -periodic homotopy of a spectrum in the usual manner: find a type spectrum with a -self map (preferably of minimal periodicity for calculational purposes), and then define to be . One can, of course, also construct this stably. Now, the bottom two cells of (i.e., the -skeleton of , although we’ll only work at the prime two because that’s what Mahowald does) for form a copy of the mod Moore space. Mahowald proved that if (which has a -self map), then this induces an isomorphism (up to shift)

Consequently, we get a -periodic version of our spectral sequence defined using the double suspension; this new spectral sequence has -page . In the same paper linked to above, Mahowald showed that the map (given by the stable projection coming from the Snaith splitting) is a -periodic isomorphism (i.e., is an isomorphism after applying the Bousfield-Kuhn functor ). The filtration of corresponding to the double suspension filtration is exactly the filtration of coming from its even-dimensional skeleta.

Here’s where things start to get wild. In this paper, Cohen constructs a map which is degree one on the bottom cell, and induces an isomorphism in -periodic homotopy. Let denote the fiber of this map; then, the -skeleton of (which is its -skeleton) is actually a copy of , our spectrum from earlier! Then, in this paper, Mahowald and Thompson show that there is a certain type spectrum for which there is a -periodic isomorphism (up to shift)

At this point, you should be convinced that whatever’s going on is not a coincidence. We should expect, for instance, that we can inductively define spaces (with , , and ) such there is a map (whose fiber is ) which is an isomorphism in -periodic homotopy, and whose bottom skeleton has cohomology which is free over (at least when ). Proving such a result is the goal of this paper of Arone’s. It’s a very dense paper…

In order to figure out what’s going on in that paper, we need to take a slight detour into Goodwillie calculus. I gave a talk about general properties of Goodwillie calculus at Juvitop a long time ago. We will let denote the category of pointed spaces, and let denote the identity on this category. Let denote the associated Taylor tower, so . If denotes the th graded piece (the th derivative), then for some naive -spectrum . Arone and Mahowald explicitly identified this -spectrum: let denote the quotient , where is the geometric realization of the poset of partitions of ordered by refining the partition, and denotes the subcomplex that does not contain the boring or trivial partition as vertices. Then is the Spanier-Whitehead dual of the suspension spectrum of .

They use this to show that is rationally contractible. (Note, for instance, that since , it follows that an odd dimensional sphere is rationally equivalent to .) In fact, they prove -local statements too: the mod homology of vanishes unless is a power of . In fact, is equivalent to , where is defined as the stable summand , where is the Steinberg idempotent in , is the reduced real regular representation of , and is the associated Thom spectrum.

One can even calculate the mod cohomology of these spectra: they find that is free over . The spectra and are classical objects, which have been well-studied. Using Nakaoka’s theorem (see, e.g., here), one can get a concrete grasp on the cohomology of these spectra. (We’ll work at for simplicity (I’m not as comfortable with the mod Steenrod algebra).)

To describe its cohomology, we need to recall the Dold-Thom theorem: if denotes the infinite symmetric power of the sphere spectrum, then . Let be the th symmetric power of the sphere spectrum; then can be shown to be . The Dold-Thom theorem gives a map , which exhibits as the quotient of the cohomology of (which is spanned by admissible monomials in the Steenrod algebra not ending in ) by the ideal generated by the admissible monomials of length . In the notes linked to above, Hopkins denotes this by . Nakaoka’s theorem implies that is isomorphic to (a shift of) , where denotes the quotient of by the ideal generated by the admissible monomials of length . As a vector space, is isomorphic to the sub-vector space of spanned by admissible monomials of length exactly which do not end in .

How about ? Define to be the cofiber of the map sending to ; this is homotopic to the map . Then . One use the description of the cohomology of above to be similarly explicit about the cohomology of : it is isomorphic as a vector space to the sub-vector space of spanned by admissible monomials of length exactly .

For instance, consider the spectrum . We can then write out basis vectors of its cohomology: these are just for . Drawing out the Steenrod module structure using the Adem relations, we find that the cohomology of in degrees is exactly that of ; in fact, the quotient of by its -cell is homotopy equivalent to . At odd primes, one replaces with .

In any case, a theorem due to Miller-Wilkerson says that if is a connected Steenrod module which is free over , then has a vanishing line of slope less than . Now, multiplication by a -self map will be given on the Adams spectral sequence by multiplication by an element living on a line of slope . So if and if is any type spectrum, then multiplication by on the mapping spectrum will necessarily be trivial. As such, is -locally trivial for .

What’s the intuition supposed to be? A theorem of Ching’s says that the collection forms an operad in spectra, and in fact, is the Lie operad from classical algebra. Since there is a Goodwillie spectral sequence whose -page is (stable homotopy), abutting to (unstable homotopy), we find that the -page of this spectral sequence is built from Lie brackets — which in the case of spheres correspond to Whitehead products — and power operations. If we rationalize and let be an odd sphere, for instance, there are no nontrivial power operations, and so the -page is just the free Lie algebra on one generator (in the dimension of the sphere). Since this generator lives in odd degree, it has no nontrivial Lie bracket/Whitehead product with itself, and we find that the -page is just a copy of in the dimension of sphere. This recovers Serre’s calculation of the stable homotopy of odd spheres. (For even spheres, it’s slightly more complicated, because the Whitehead product of the identity with itself is no longer rationally trivial, and we find that the -page is .) The fact that is -locally trivial for tells us that after inverting , the -page of this spectral sequence is only concentrated in a few lines. By our discussion above, this is a statement about (unstable) Lie brackets and power operations in the -local setting. This is discussed in more detail in Mark’s book, which I’m hoping to better understand.

In any case, the upshot of this is that if is an odd-dimensional sphere, the -periodic Goodwillie spectral sequence only has layers (namely, through ). So the (unstable) -periodic homotopy type of has a filtration whose associated graded is ; this is the same as the associated graded of the Goodwillie derivative filtration of , and the map is in fact a -periodic homotopy equivalence. The idea of the proof of this final claim is to write the fiber, say , of the map as an inverse limit of a tower , whose layers are each for , and use the fact that multiplication by acts on any element in (where is a finite type spectrum) in the Adams spectral sequence by multiplication by an element living in a slope higher than the vanishing line of the Adams spectral sequence for . This argument is sketched as the proof of Theorem 3.6 on page 15 of this survey; it’s clear that the argument is rather general, and could be applied to other situations too.

We can now return back to the paper of Arone’s we originally wanted to understand. In all of this, we considered the th layer of the Goodwillie spectral sequence for the identity on pointed space, and finally concluded that only of them were nontrivial after inverting ; this told us that is equivalent to after inverting . Mahowald’s and Mahowald-Thompson’s work that we talked about in the beginning of this post suggests that trying to understand the layers might suggest a generalization of the results we mentioned at the very beginning of this post. To understand this, we need to actually define , and then study its layers. Cohen’s definition of (on spheres) involved hard calculations in unstable homotopy theory, but Weiss observed that one can actually construct it in a lot more generality.

Let denote the category of complex vector spaces with a positive definite inner product and isometries, and let be a functor. Let denote the fiber of the map . Then Weiss showed that if , there is a functor defined on objects by such that the obvious map lifts the map , where the map is given by evaluation on . If we now define to be for some space , then is the fiber of the double suspension map . Moreover, , so the result cited above says that there is a natural map . When is the sphere (which we’ll always assume), then is , and this map is precisely Cohen’s map (at ).

Having obtained this map , we inductively define to be the fiber of the induced map . In Weiss’ original paper, it’s shown that is equivalent to , where is regarded as a subgroup of via the reduced standard representation. Let’s write this as . The main point of Arone’s paper is to calculate the homology of when is an odd-dimensional sphere — he shows that it vanishes for not a power of a prime, and, like for , it’s free over if . In fact, he shows that it’s the exactly homology of tensored up with the exterior algebra generated by the Chern classes of .

The argument used in the linked survey to show that is a -periodic equivalence (when is an odd sphere, which will remain true for the rest of this post) in fact applies to this situation as well (as one can see from the sketch of the proof of Theorem 3.6 on page 15, all one needs to ensure is true in this case is that the cohomology of each layer is free over for (so you know the vanishing line of its Adams -page), and that the connectivity of the mapping spectrum is sufficiently large), and we find that the map is a -periodic equivalence for . In fact, if is the smallest integer for which (so ), then has trivial -periodic homotopy for (because vanishes, by Weiss’ formula, for , and hence does too for ). Moreover, since (again by Weiss’ formula and our choice of given ), we find that the map is a -periodic equivalence. In other words, .

Recall that Mahowald proved (in our notation) that is (a shift of; remember, is an odd-dimensional sphere) . One can apparently just calculate that is just a shift of , so our discussion above recovers Mahowald’s result. Similarly, Arone claims that Mahowald-Thompson’s result also follows by a calculation. In any case, it is clear that the “correct” generalization of Mahowald et al’s results is given by Arone’s theorem.
